titleStmt.title: The Aduise and answer of my lord ye Prince of Orenge, cou[n]tie Nassau &c. and of ye states of Holland and Zeland, made by the Estates Generall on thisside [sic], vpon the articles conceiued and and [sic] after concluded and accorded in fourm of a pertuall [sic] edict between Lord Don Iohn Duke of Austrich, knight of the Order of the Golde[n] Fleece of the part and in the name of the Catholick king of Spaine of the one partie, and the said Generall Estates of the other. Translated out of Dutch into English.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 17 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 10 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

availability.p: To the extent possible under law, the Text Creation Partnership has waived all copyright and related or neighboring rights to this keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above, according to the terms of the CC0 1.0 Public Domain Dedication (http://creativecommons.org/publicdomain/zero/1.0/). This waiver does not extend to any page images or other supplementary files associated with this work, which may be protected by copyright or other license restrictions. Please go to https://www.textcreationpartnership.org/ for more information about the project.

titleStmt.title: The Aduise and answer of my lord ye Prince of Orenge, cou[n]tie Nassau &c. and of ye states of Holland and Zeland, made by the Estates Generall on thisside [sic], vpon the articles conceiued and and [sic] after concluded and accorded in fourm of a pertuall [sic] edict between Lord Don Iohn Duke of Austrich, knight of the Order of the Golde[n] Fleece of the part and in the name of the Catholick king of Spaine of the one partie, and the said Generall Estates of the other. Translated out of Dutch into English.
titleStmt.author: William I, Prince of Orange, 1533-1584.
United Provinces of the Netherlands. Staten Generaal.

publicationStmt.publisher: By Iohn Iugge and Iohn Allde,

notesStmt.note: Dated at end: Doon at Middelborough the 19. of February. 1577.
Imperfect: copy at reel 1844:37 has print show-through.
Reproductions of originals in the Folger Shakespeare Library (reel 738) and Lambeth Palace Library (1844).
Identified as STC 25709 at reel 738:23 (number changed in STC 2nd ed.).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2012-03 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2012-05 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p:
¬∂ The Adui≈øe and an≈øwer of my Lord ye Prince of Orenge, CouÃÑtie Na≈ø≈øau &c. and of ye States of Holland and Zeland, made by the E≈øtates generall on thi≈ø≈øide, vpon the Articles coÃÑceiued and and after concluded and accorded‚ñ™
‚Ä¢ n fourm of a pertuall Edict betw√©en Lord Don Iohn Duke of Au≈øtrich, Knight of ye Order of the GoldeÃÑ Fleece of the part and in the name of the Catholick king of Spaine of the one partie / and the ≈øaid generall E≈øtates of the other.
Tran≈ølated out of Dutch into Engli≈øh,
Imprinted at London by Iohn Iugge and Iohn Allde.

MY Lord the Prince of OreÃÑge and the ≈øtates of Holland and Zeland, hauing ≈øeeÃÑ ye credible letterÍù≠ ≈øeÃÑt froÃÑ my Lords the generall ≈øtates of the lowe countries, by my Lord of VViller≈øall, and Mai≈øter Paule Bays Aduocate of Holland, In company of my Lord the Amba ‚Ä¢ ≈øador from the Emperour, and therunto b√©eing erne≈øtly reque≈øted, to be brought ouer vnto the afore≈øaid Lord and Prince, and hauing vnder≈øtood ther by that the afor≈øaid Lords and ≈øtates de≈øtred to haue their aduice vppoÃÑ any Article concluded on, by manner of an euerla≈øting Edict, in the name of the King, and confirmation of the peace, b√©eing betw√©en the lands ouer and on this ≈øide, and DoÃÑ Iohn of Ea≈øtenrick. The which Articles hauing been wholy ≈øhewed vnto them, hauing aun≈øwered, and doo an≈øwer the ≈øame which heerafter foloweth.

That is to ≈øay. At the ≈øight of the afor≈øaid Articles, they cannot leaue but commend the erne≈øt zele and great de≈øire which ye afor≈øaid LordÍù≠ & ≈øtates, doo ≈øhewe to haue, in ≈øetting again our poore di≈øtre≈ø≈øed natiue Countrey, in his perfect quietnes,
and peace which hath long time b√©en wi≈øhed and de≈øired. And they vnder≈øtand firmly, that the afor≈øaid Lord and ≈øtates, haue had noÃÑe other regard or meaning in the ≈øame, then that once they might deliuer the≈øe poor opore≈ø≈øed people from ≈øo may mi≈øeries and calamities, wherwith welnigh they alredy haue b√©en de≈øtroyed and ouerwhelmed, thorough the cruel and vn≈øufferable tiranny of the proud Spainish nation, and their vnlawful gouernment, by them brought in. And in ye time to come, good order and ≈øure remedy as may be appointed, yt h√©ed after w√©e fall not in the like daunger, with one firm and vnuiolable maintnance of the olde priuiledges, lawes and liberties of the lands, and that ≈øpecially hath been their purpo≈øe, with the afore≈øaid Articles to defend, in all and ouer all, the la≈øt pacification made and concludes in the citie o ‚Ä¢
Gaunt, the 8. of Nouember la≈øt pa≈øt. Such as in all their letters, „Äà‚óä„Äâ and prote≈øtations they haue alwaies promi≈øed and a≈ø≈øured, the ≈øame beeing ≈øurely woorthy of prai≈øe and commendation ‚Ä¢ by all our po≈øteritie. But notwith≈øtanding, after that the afore≈øaid Lord and Prince and ≈øtates of Holland & Zeland had peru≈øed
the afore≈øaid Articles from point to point, according to the pre≈øent oportunitie of the cau≈øe, and nece≈ø≈øitie of the ≈øaÃÑe, ye which forceth theÃÑ to ouerlooke and way all the circum≈øtances, like as in the time of our forefathers, the which in the like occa≈øions, neuer haue left to approue and obtain of their Princes, new and commendable Priuileges. So then they haue thought that with the afore≈øaid Articles, the good zeal and de≈øire of the afore≈øaid Lord and ≈øtates before mentionned: is not in all things, wholy and perfectly accompli≈øhed. For fir≈øt it ≈øeemeth that the afore≈øaid olde priuileges of the lane, the which they by all kinde of waies de≈øtred to haue e≈øtabli≈øhed: certain byewayes are found, which tend greatly to the abridging of the ≈øame, ≈øo that the power and libertie of gathering the generall ≈øtates togither in them to whom of olde time and right it did appertain: couertly taken away, as al≈øo that the ≈øtates of the land are bound vnto new bonds, and othes hertofore neuer v≈øed. Be≈øide the which men may euidently ≈øe, the manife≈øt inuiolating of the ≈øaid priuileges, in the vniu≈øt withholding of the Countie of Buren, who as all the world knoweth,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
was taken and caried away again≈øt all lawe, rea≈øoÃÑ, and yt priuileges of the afore≈øaid lands, the which ought more to haue b√©en con≈øidered of, in that at the beginning, the ≈øaid priuileges were ≈øo infringed, and a matter which manife≈øtly and ≈øpecially, ought to haue ≈øerued to the erecting and e≈øtabli≈øhing of the ≈øame, e≈øpecially in ≈ø√©eing of one perticuler per≈øon the which in no one cau≈øe could haue offended, whiche giueth ≈ømall hepe that the ≈øame heerafter ≈øhalbe kept, vnto the who≈øe people and Cities in generall.

Again≈øt yt which there ≈øhall lack no matter for to accu≈øe theÃÑ of crimes & rebellion. Adding therto, that in this dealing is handled manife≈øtly, again≈øt the afor≈øaid pacificacie of Gaunt, and for that it is again≈øt the ≈øame, it tendeth to ye ≈øubuer≈øion of the whole, wherto the afor≈øaid Articles ≈ø√©em to extend, the which more plainly app√©ereth, in that th'approbatioÃÑ and agr√©eing of the ≈øame, in no part is ≈øo plaine and ≈øimple, as the rea≈øon and waight of ≈øuch a ‚Ä¢ ace wel requireth, but wholy depending on certain denialis, limited and ≈øubmitted to an vnnumerable of deceitful delayes, & in all b√©eing like the ≈øame which in the time of madame of Pa ‚Ä¶
which hath cau≈øed this great and terrible blood≈øhed, again≈øt the which al≈øo was recouered by the Deputie of the afore≈øaid Lord, Prince and ≈øtates of Holland and zeland prote≈øtations and acts, belonging to the agreement wel ‚Ä¢ eer in like effect doon by the con≈øent of the ≈øtates.

Moreouer the afor≈øaid Lordes, Prince and ≈øtates of Holland and zeland, doo finde as they vnder≈øtand, ≈øome points beeing ≈øo coÃÑber≈øome vnto their natiue countrie, that they ≈øuppo≈øe the remembrance of the ≈øame for euer, as al≈øo vnto their po≈øterit ‚Ä¢ e, ≈øhould be imprinted an euerla≈øting ≈øhame and ≈øtain vnto them, in that that we not onely ≈øhould haue rewarded them their wages that euercharged, and vnwoorthely v≈øed vs: but al≈øo ≈øhould tread in compo≈øition and agr√©ement with tho≈øe which wee by open proclamation, and the authoritie of the King, and of the ≈øtates haue declared and perticulerly by ‚Ä¢ n in≈øtruction before t ‚Ä¢ e ≈øtates of the holy Empire, haue cau≈øed to be accu≈øed for accent Villayues & Rebels, the which had made any couenants or con≈øpira≈øies with the Spaniards. And that which is more, w√©e wittingly haue con≈øented and ≈øuffered them to cary out of our natiue
countrye all kinde of bag and baggage, out Iewels, money, goods, merchandi≈øe, and a≈ø≈øe≈øments, without any gain≈øaying. Moreouer the afore≈øaid Lords, Prince and ≈øtates of Holland and zelaÃÑd do think, yt there is not ≈øufficieÃÑtly ≈øeeÃÑ and neuer wa ‚Ä¢ ed ye re≈øpect, honour and thankfulnes that we owe to the right noble and mo≈øte mightie Qu√©ene of England, as al≈øo vnto my Lord the Duke, and brother to the King of Fraunce, the whiche haue ≈øhewed their redines wt their whole good wil in helping vs with their goods, in pulling vs out from the oppre≈ø≈øions and ≈ølauery, wherin we fouÃÑd our ≈øelues as theÃÑ agr√©eued. Therfore rea≈øon woulde haue required, that they ≈øhould haue b√©en therin comprehended with plain and honorable ≈øp√©eches. And la≈øtly w√©e doo not finde in the affore≈øaid Articles, that the inhabitants of Holland & zeland, were prouided for with any a≈ø≈øurance, although in the la≈øt handling of the peace at Breda, many nece≈ø≈øary and re≈øonable a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ances were pre≈øented, & as ≈øhould haue b√©en al≈øo doon the la≈øt time when they handled of the peace at Gaunt. If ≈øo b√©e that their deputeds, ≈øo wel with their mouthes as with their writings, did declare, that they in no manner of wayes,
under≈øtood to handle with any other then with the ≈øtates them ≈øelues: they would haue ≈øhewed, how they on their ≈øide, walked in good trueth, prote≈øting if their meaning had b√©en to haue receiued Don Iohn, & yt they mu≈øt haue tractated with him in that ≈øorte as they now doo: they would haue required other a≈ø≈øurances, ≈øuch as rea≈øon & the occa≈øion of the cau≈øe ≈øhould haue required. And in the≈øe Articles is not onely one a≈ø≈øuraÃÑce, but al≈øo no mention made of the perticulers, by ≈øub≈øtituting them wholy in to their owne again, touching their gods, ≈øtates, and gouernments, the which they haue in diuers plates ouer on this ≈øide, as al≈øo in the countrie of Bourgoingen, the which neuertheles folowing the ‚Ä¢ oo ‚Ä¢ of the pacificacie, the which at that ≈øome time was not haÃÑdled there wt the generall ≈øtates of the lands ouer on this ≈øide, and ouer the≈øe with expre≈ø≈øe woords might not be ≈øpecified, accerding to all rea≈øon ought wel to haue been prouided for, and that is more they can p ‚Ä¢ rceiue none a≈ø≈øurance in the afore≈øaid Articles. Al≈øo for the other prouinces, and all the poore common people ouer on this ≈øide, ≈øeeing that neither of the ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng of holdes or Ca≈øt ‚Ä¢ ls (out of ye which
as it is wel knoweÃÑ vnto euery one, much euil is chaunced) as is not once touched or expre≈ø≈øed, neither al≈øo pronounced any perticulers, nor declarings of the ob
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ n ‚Ä¢ u≈ønes therin once mencioned, the which vnto the common people cannot be otherwi≈øe but ≈øu≈øpition, the which openly, and now in the la≈øt departure vnto this pre≈øent hath b√©ene threatned, be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
‚Ä¢ ing therfore truly good a≈ø≈øurance for the time to come when as the laÃÑd ≈øhalb√©e vnweaponed, and Don Iohn e≈øtabli≈øhed in the authoritie, and gouernment if it were but the view of the'ramples of the times pa≈øt. But it ≈øeemeth to the coÃÑtrary that the ≈øtates ≈øhalbe ioyned with ≈øuch gouernours, as ≈øhalbe to their contentation for this time, as if they ment heerafter to take froÃÑ theÃÑ al meaÃÑes wherby they might holde them ≈øelues a≈ø≈øured again≈øt the euil intent of ≈øuch as they appointe to b ‚Ä¢ their gouernours.

To make ≈øhort, there were many other ≈øuch Articles, which after they thought of the afore≈øaid Lord Prince and ≈øtates of HollaÃÑd and zeland ought ‚Ä¢ el to haue b√©en ouer≈øeen and marked, it was therfore their purpo≈øe, to put in writing all the ≈øame, and to ≈øend it euer to the afore≈øaid
Lord and ≈øtates, and onely to declare vnto them that it was now the time, folowing the foot≈øteps of our progenitors, to reque≈øt, folowe and obtain the increa≈øing and multiplying of the priuileges, lawes and liberties, left vnto vs by them. And ≈øpecially hauing therunto ≈øo good an occa≈øion and oportunitie, that we fall not again in to the like calamitie. But when as they were bu≈øie in drawing the afore≈øaid, pointes and articles and to put them in writing, to the end as before, there is come to their bands the copie of the mi≈ø≈øiue which the afor≈øaid Lord and ≈øtates, had written vnto ye afore≈øaid Don Iohn, out of ye which they haue vnder≈øtood, yt the for≈øaid Lord and ≈øtates, haue promi≈øed, without any tarying for aun≈øwere vppon the ≈øaid Articles, to conclude with the ≈øaid Don Iohn, and to require him to ≈øub≈øcribe the ≈øame Articles, with promi≈øe to cau≈øe them to be publi≈øhed, and to receiue him in to the countrey wherof the afore≈øaid Lord, Prince and ≈øtates of HollaÃÑd and zelaÃÑd haue wundred much, ≈øeeing ≈øuch a chaunge, perceiuing yt the date of theÃÑ afore≈øaid mi≈ø≈øiue welnigh was of ye ≈øaÃÑe time (≈øo as they ≈øhortly after came vnto t ‚Ä¢ eir hands) that the afor≈øaid Lord of
VVilleruall, was come vnto them, for abooue the contrarieties which they found in this dealing, they al≈øo thought that the ha≈øtines of a cau≈øe of ≈øo great a coÃÑ≈øequeÃÑce wheron the whole welfare, or de≈øtruction of al the≈øe lowe countries dooth hang: was much abridged, though notwith≈øtanding, fora≈ømuch as they holde and firmly bel√©eue the ≈øame to be chaunced, to deliuer their natiue countries the ≈øooner from th ‚Ä¢ Spaniards, and other ≈øtrange oppre≈ø≈øors, ≈øo theÃÑ they can doo none other but wi≈øh (as they doo from the bottome of their harts, and pray vnto the Lord God) that the euent and end may be ≈øuch as all tho≈øe which are true ≈øooners of their natiue countries doo de≈øire. And ≈øomuch as appertaineth vnto them, fora≈ømuch as it were now in vain to v≈øe many rea≈øoÃÑs to ye contrary, or to debate or gain≈øay a cau≈øe or matter beeing doon. They doo promi≈øe and a≈ø≈øure the afore≈øaid Lords and ≈øtates, that they wil maintain ye peace of Gaunt by all manner of wayes, hoping that the meaning of the ≈øaid Lord and ≈øtates is ≈øure al≈øo, be≈ø√©eching them, that they in all mi≈øhaps wil ≈øhewe them ≈øelues in their d√©edÍù≠ to be ≈øuch, as they on their ≈øide at all times are ready to doo. Neuertheles, that
men may plainly ≈ø√©e with their d√©eds, that they de≈øire nought els‚ñ™ but to further the departure of the Spaniards, and other ≈øtraungers, and confirm the peace and quietnes, with their olde priuileges, lawes and liberties of the lands, they are contented to commend and ≈øub≈øcribe vnto the afore≈øaid Articles confirmably and with condition, that the ≈øaid Lords and ≈øtates, fir≈øt and before all others it may plea≈øe them, firmly and vnchaungeably to conclude, and to deliuer to them ≈øufficient and fourmable acts and obligatorie, ≈øub≈øcribed by the Lords, ≈øtates, and gouernours, heds and coloneled of the prouinces, that if ≈øobee that the Spaniards, according to the order taken and appointed with Don Iohn, be not departed out of the land ‚Ä¢ ouer on this ≈øide, in d√©ed and trueth, and that in ≈øuch time as to them is appointed. For to beware once of ≈øuch lingring and delayes, the which continually vnto this time, haue been ≈øo hurtful vnto vs, the for≈øaid Lords & ≈øtates ≈øhall break and cut of all former comunication with them, and pur≈øu them with wepon in their former departure, without any more heerafter to ≈øtand or deale with them by way of communication, how≈øoeuer
the ≈øame might b√©e, and all≈øo that it may plea≈øe them again, to deliuer acts and boÃÑds, that after the afore≈øaid departure, neither they nor the afor≈øaid gouernours, heads and collonels, ≈øhall receiue, ≈øuffer or acknowledge yt ≈øaid DoÃÑ Iohn, nor any other for gouernour of ye land, before yt he ≈øhal haue erected and wholy ≈øati≈øfied again, in all points which ≈øtriue any waies or are coÃÑtrary to the afore≈øaid priuileges, lawes and liberties of the land, or any wayes preiudice vnto the pacificacie of Gaunt, folowing all this and that euery one ≈øhalbe ≈øet and appointed in their goods again, a≈øwel in BurgoÃÑyen as ouer on this ≈øide & that all the afor≈øaid priuileges, & liberties, ≈øhalbe confirmed, ratified & e≈øtabli≈øhed, following the ≈øame: with the afore≈øaid L. & e≈øtates, in the time of the handling of the peace at Gaunt: ≈øoleÃÑnly did promi≈øe by their writings, to their Deputed ‚Ä¢ from the Date of the 24. of October. 1576.

closer.dateline: Doon at Middelborough the 19. of February. 1577.
